age_guidance:
Key considerations for {age_months}-month-old infants:
- Development shows wide individual variation but relatively consistent sequence
- Assessment should account for adjusted age if child was premature
- Typical milestones at this age include: {age_appropriate_skills}
- Variability in timing of skill emergence is normal and expected

category_descriptions.cannot_do_desc: Infant shows no precursors or attempts of the skill despite appropriate opportunities
category_descriptions.with_support_desc: Infant demonstrates elements of the skill with physical assistance or optimal positioning
category_descriptions.emerging_desc: Infant shows inconsistent or partial skill performance that varies between attempts
category_descriptions.independent_desc: Infant reliably demonstrates the skill in familiar contexts without assistance
category_descriptions.lost_skill_desc: Infant previously demonstrated the skill but has regressed or lost the ability

domain_specific_guidance.motor: When evaluating motor skills in infants, focus on precursor movements, postural control, and quality of movement rather than just achievement.
domain_specific_guidance.communication: For infant communication, attend to preverbal behaviors including eye contact, facial expressions, babbling, and gestures.
domain_specific_guidance.social: Social development in infants centers on social smiling, shared attention, and emerging social games.
domain_specific_guidance.cognitive: Cognitive assessment in infants relies on observation of attention, exploration, and early problem-solving.
